Legal_Issue: Whether Pfizer's patent is valid and whether Apotex's process infringes the patent claims
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of regulatory approval application
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, prior art, chemical equivalence analysis
Decision_Outcome: Pfizer's patent is valid; Apotex's process infringes the patent
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to prove patent invalidity
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony on chemical properties and processes
Legal_Rule: A patent is presumed valid unless proven otherwise; infringement occurs if a process uses obvious chemical equivalents
Grounds_for_Claim: Apotex alleged non-infringement and patent invalidity based on prior art
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment under Patent Act
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Full hearing with opportunity to present evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior patents, unexpected properties of fluconazole, ACIC Pathway vs. patented process
Applicant_Challenge: Apotex challenged patent validity and claimed non-infringement
Defendant_Response: Denial of infringement and challenge to patent validity
Remedy_Requested: Prevention of regulatory approval for generic drug
Outcome: Prohibition order granted; Apotex barred until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Section 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Prior art, lack of novelty, non-infringement
